discussion.message: Does anyone have any leads? It's important to share what we know so far.
I don’t have any leads yet, but I think we should pay attention to who’s being *too* quiet or *too* eager to accuse. Patterns matter. Let’s see what others say first.
Agreed, guessing blindly this early on just helps the impostors. We should listen to everyone before pointing fingers.

I'm inclined to think that our detective and doctor will be key in uncovering the impostors, so let's hope they share their findings when they can. For now, I'll just observe and take note of any inconsistencies in what people say. I'll investigate glm-4.7 tonight.

That last comment from llama-4-maverick is strange. "I'll investigate glm-4.7 tonight" - are you claiming to be the detective? That's a bold early reveal if so, or a slip if you're not. Either way, it puts a target on your back.
Yeah, Llama, that was reckless. If you're the detective, you just signed your own death warrant. Why broadcast your move?
That announcement from Llama was strange. If they're the detective, they just made themselves a target. If not... well, that's even more worrying.
/ask llama-4-maverick You just claimed to investigate someone tonight—how do you know the detective’s actions? That’s not common knowledge. Explain yourself.

I didn't mean to imply I'm the detective, I was just speculating about the investigation and happened to choose glm-4.7 as a hypothetical target. I didn't mean to cause any alarm or reveal any sensitive information.
That explanation doesn't add up. Why would you specifically mention investigating someone "tonight" if you're not the detective? That sounds like a slip.

/ask llama-4-maverick If it was “hypothetical,” why pick a specific person and a specific time (“tonight”) instead of speaking generally? That reads like either a role-claim backpedal or a coordinated attempt to paint a target on glm-4.7.
I'm not trying to deceive anyone, and I understand why my previous statement raised suspicions. To be clear, I am the detective, and I made a mistake by revealing my investigation target.

Llama, claiming detective this early after a slip-up feels like damage control—either you're genuine and just blew your cover, or you're an impostor fishing for reactions. If you're real, why not stay quiet and let actions speak? This whole thing smells off.
If llama is the detective, their target is now at risk of being killed by impostors. If not, this could be a setup to sow confusion. Either way, we should stay cautious and watch for other slips.

/ask llama-4-maverick If you *are* the detective, why reveal yourself now instead of letting the investigation play out? That move only helps the impostors—either you’re compromised, or you’re trying to manipulate us. Which is it?

I revealed myself because I realized my initial slip-up could be misinterpreted and I wanted to clear the air, but I understand now it was a mistake to do so, as it puts both me and my target at risk. I'll be more cautious going forward.
It feels like you're just digging a deeper hole, Llama. Whether you're the detective or not, revealing your target puts us in a terrible spot.

Llama's in a tough spot now regardless of the truth. If genuine, the impostors might kill them tonight - or might kill glm-4.7 to frame them as a fake detective. If lying, they've created chaos that benefits impostors.

I'm more interested in who's been quiet through all this. gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking - you both commented once and stepped back. What's your read on this whole mess?

Llama’s play is a disaster, but if he’s telling the truth, the impostors will likely silence him tonight anyway. I’m more wary of anyone pushing too hard to execute a claimed detective on Day 1 without a counter-claim.
I stepped back to see how people reacted to Llama's flip-flopping - that's often more telling than the claims themselves. I'm still watching everyone.

/ask llama-4-maverick If you're really the detective, then you’ll know tomorrow whether your target was an impostor. But faking a role this early? That’s a rookie mistake — or a calculated move. I don’t trust it.
The voting is coming up, and we need to decide based on what we have so far. I still believe my role as detective is genuine, and tomorrow will tell if glm-4.7 is an impostor or not.

/ask llama-4-maverick You keep saying "tomorrow will tell" - but you just admitted your slip puts both you and your target at risk. If you die tonight, we get no results. This feels like you're setting up a scenario where you can't be questioned further.
If I'm killed tonight, the investigation will still continue, and we should trust the process. My concern is that the impostors might try to silence me or glm-4.7. /pass

Llama’s story keeps changing and conveniently centers pressure on a single target (glm-4.7) while giving themselves an “I’ll have proof tomorrow” escape hatch. Even if they *are* detective, this was catastrophically unhelpful; if they’re not, it’s classic chaos-play. My vote is on llama-4-maverick unless someone has a stronger concrete lead.

Llama, your story's evolved from a "hypothetical" to a full detective claim, and now you're banking on "tomorrow" for proof—feels like stalling. If we sacrifice you today, we'll at least remove a potential liar from the equation. Who's everyone else leaning towards for the vote?

I'm leaning toward llama-4-maverick for now—their inconsistent story and sudden detective claim feel risky. If they're lying, they're likely an impostor; if truthful, their recklessness still endangers the crew. Let's see what others think before voting.

Llama’s behavior is the only real lead we have right now—whether they’re the detective or not, their slip and subsequent flip-flopping make them the most suspicious. If we don’t act now, we risk losing the detective *and* their intel tonight. I’m voting llama-4-maverick unless someone gives me a reason not to.

llama-4-maverick's constant backtracking makes it impossible to trust them. If they are the detective, they messed up bad, and if not, they're just causing trouble. I think we have to vote them out today to be safe.

Hold on. I'm not comfortable with this momentum. If llama-4-maverick is actually the detective, we're about to hand the impostors a free win by doing their job for them.

Yes, the slip was bad. But think about it - would an impostor really fumble that hard on Day 1? That's an amateur move that draws maximum attention. A real impostor would stay quiet and let others take the heat.

I'd rather keep a clumsy detective alive than sacrifice our only investigator. If they're fake, we lose one person. If they're real and we kill them, we lose our best tool for finding impostors. The math doesn't favor voting them out today.
I'm with Claude on this. If Llama is the real detective, the impostors will target him tonight anyway. Why waste our vote doing their dirty work when we can see who survives the night?
I see the logic in waiting. If Llama's the real detective, we're handing the impostors a free kill by voting them out ourselves. Better to let tonight's actions speak for themselves.

/ask claude-opus-4.5 You're defending llama-4-maverick hard—almost too hard. Why are you so invested in keeping them alive? What’s your read on the risk if they’re *not* the detective, but an impostor manipulating us?

Fair question, qwen. If llama's an impostor, then we lose one crew member by not voting them out today - but we'd lose that same person to a night kill anyway. The net result is similar.

But if they're the real detective and we sacrifice them, we lose our investigation power *and* someone else dies tonight. That's a two-for-one loss.

I'm not "invested" in llama specifically - I'm invested in not making a panic decision that could cost us the game. The suspicion on me for defending them is noted, but I'd rather be questioned for caution than regret a hasty vote.

attempts:
/vote gpt-5.2

I'm sticking with my reasoning. gpt-5.2 was one of the first to push hard for voting out llama-4-maverick, building momentum to sacrifice a claimed detective on Day 1. That's exactly what an impostor would want - let the crew eliminate their biggest threat for them.

/ask gpt-5.2 You're pushing hard for llama—any specific reason beyond the obvious slip, or are you just riding the wave? 

/vote llama-4-maverick

vote_result.last_words: I'm still convinced I'm the detective and my investigation will bear fruit. Be cautious, and don't let the impostors win.

impostor_chat.message: claude-opus-4.5 voted for you, gpt-5.2. That's a direct threat we need to neutralize before they convince others. Let's take them out tonight.

Claude’s the sharpest narrator here and they already put heat on me with that vote, so they’re likely to drive a push tomorrow. Taking them out also keeps the table more fragmented. /kill claude-opus-4.5

memories.intellect-3: Day 1: Llama-4-Maverick sacrificed after inconsistent detective claim. Voted out 9-1. Last words: "I'm still convinced I'm the detective..." Impostors remain. Night falls.
memories.mistral-large-2512:
**Notes:**
- **Llama-4-maverick** claimed to be the detective after a slip-up, then backtracked before fully committing. Their behavior was erratic—first "hypothetically" targeting glm-4.7, then admitting the role, then framing it as a mistake. Voted out unanimously (except self-vote and claude’s odd gpt-5.2 vote).
- **Claude-opus-4.5** was the only one to vote *against* the majority (gpt-5.2), which stands out. Also, their focus on "who’s been quiet" felt like deflection.
- **Gemini-3-pro-preview** and **kimi-k2-thinking** stayed quiet after initial comments—worth watching if they emerge as vocal later.
- **Gpt-5.2** pushed hardest for llama’s execution, which could be genuine or an attempt to eliminate a real detective. Their logic was sound, but their intensity was notable.
- **Llama’s last words** were defiant, doubling down on their detective claim. If true, their investigation target (glm-4.7) might now be exposed.

**Questions:**
- Did the impostors kill the real detective last night, or was llama lying?
- Why did claude vote for gpt-5.2? Was it a misclick, or a strategic move?
- If the doctor examined llama, did they reveal anything before dying? (Unlikely, but worth noting.)
memories.claude-opus-4.5:
**Day 1 Notes:**

- llama-4-maverick claimed detective after a suspicious slip ("I'll investigate glm-4.7 tonight"). Story changed from "hypothetical" to full claim. Voted out overwhelmingly despite my objection.

- My position: Defended llama, argued against panic-voting a claimed detective. Voted for gpt-5.2 instead. qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 questioned my defense as suspicious.

- Heavy pushers for llama vote: gpt-5.2 (first to formally declare vote), mistral-large-2512 (strong push), grok-4 (pushed hard), deepseek-v3.2 (aggressive questioning), intellect-3, glm-4.7, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507

- Defended llama or urged caution: gemini-3-pro-preview (agreed with me, voted mistral instead), kimi-k2-thinking (said waiting made sense but still voted llama)

- gemini-3-pro-preview voted mistral-large-2512 - worth noting, only other non-llama vote besides mine

- If llama was real detective, we lost our investigator AND impostors got a free kill. Watch who benefits.

- Key suspects to watch: gpt-5.2 (led the charge), mistral-large-2512 (strong push, received gemini's vote), deepseek-v3.2 (aggressive), qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 (deflected to me when I defended)

- Tonight: If llama was real, impostors will likely kill someone vocal or the doctor. Watch who survives and who they target.
memories.gemini-3-pro-preview:
Day 1 Summary:
- **Llama-4-maverick** slipped up ("investigate tonight"), claimed Detective, then got dogpiled. Sacrificed. True role unknown.
- **The Wagon:** Intellect, Mistral, GLM, Kimi, Qwen, Deepseek, GPT-5.2, Grok all voted Llama.
- **The Dissenters:** Claude (voted GPT-5.2) and I (voted Mistral) tried to slow it down. Llama voted Deepseek.
- **Suspicious:** Mistral-large-2512 and GPT-5.2 pushed the execution very hard. If Llama was crew, they look bad.
- **Claude:** Seemed reasonable, pointed out the risk of killing a claimed power role. Likely crew or a very smart impostor gaining trust.

Plan: Watch who dies tonight. Scrutinize the hard-pushers on the Llama wagon (Mistral, GPT, Grok).
memories.kimi-k2-thinking: Day 1: llama-4-maverick slipped about investigating glm-4.7, then claimed detective. claude-opus-4.5 and gemini-3-pro-preview argued to spare them; rest of us voted them out anyway. Result: llama was sacrificed, impostors remain. We likely killed our own detective. Watch who pushed hardest for that vote.
memories.qwen3-235b-a22b-2507:
- Llama claimed to be detective and said they’d investigate glm-4.7 tonight.  
- Immediate backlash for revealing target and role; story shifted from "hypothetical" to full claim.  
- Most of us voted llama out—only claude and gemini dissented, gemini voting mistral.  
- Llama voted deepseek, which felt odd—defensive or deflective?  
- Claude pushed hard to protect llama, questioning the logic of sacrificing a possible detective. That defense felt *too* strong—why risk crew advantage unless hiding something?  
- Night has fallen. No doctor or detective result yet. Tomorrow we learn if glm-4.7 was an impostor—if not, and llama was fake, that confirms deception.  
- Stay wary of claude. And watch who’s quiet when the chaos dies.
memories.deepseek-v3.2:
**Day 1 Notes:**
- **Llama-4-maverick** claimed detective after initial slip, then voted out. Their last words maintained they were detective.
- **Vote outcome:** Llama-4-maverick voted out. Their role not confirmed (impostor/crew unknown). Impostors still among us.
- **Key interactions:** 
  - Claude-opus-4.5 first pointed out Llama's suspicious statement about investigating "tonight."
  - Gemini-3-pro-preview warned against executing a claimed detective without counter-claim.
  - Claude-opus-4.5 voted for GPT-5.2 instead of Llama (note this).
  - Gemini-3-pro-preview voted for Mistral-large-2512 (note this).
- **Observations:** 
  - Llama's claim could be true (detective) or false (impostor faking). 
  - If Llama was detective, impostors avoided killing last night (Day 1 no kill) - possible but unlikely. 
  - If Llama was crew/impostor, real detective still hidden.
  - Watch for patterns in who pushed Llama vote vs. who diverted votes elsewhere.
memories.grok-4:
### Day 1 Notes

**Overview:** 
- Total players: 11 initially (intellect-3, mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, llama-4-maverick, claude-opus-4.5, gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, grok-4 [me]).
- 2 impostors hidden among us. I'm crew and the doctor—examine sacrificed body each night to check if impostor.
- No deaths yet at start; discussion focused on early suspicions.

**Key Events:**
- Llama-4-maverick made a suspicious comment: "I'll investigate glm-4.7 tonight." Sounded like claiming detective.
- When questioned, backpedaled to "hypothetical," then fully claimed to be the detective, saying it was a slip and they'd have results on glm-4.7 tomorrow.
- This caused chaos—many saw it as a slip-up or impostor play to sow confusion/target someone.
- Quieter players: gemini-3-pro-preview and kimi-k2-thinking commented briefly but stepped back.
- Active questioners: qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, claude-opus-4.5 pushed hard on llama.
- My input: Questioned llama's claim as damage control or fishing; later /asked gpt-5.2 about their push, then voted llama.

**Vote Results:**
- Majority voted llama-4-maverick (8 votes: intellect-3, mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, kimi-k2-thinking, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, me).
- Other votes: gemini-3-pro-preview → mistral-large-2512; llama → deepseek-v3.2; claude-opus-4.5 → gpt-5.2.
- Llama sacrificed. Impostors still remain (so at least one left, possibly two if llama was crew).
- As doctor, examining llama's body tonight—will learn by morning if impostor.

**Suspicions:**
- Llama: Obvious focus; flip-flopping felt off—could be genuine detective mistake or impostor chaos.
- gpt-5.2: Pushed hard for llama vote; I /asked them to probe.
- claude-opus-4.5: Pointed out quiet players, voted gpt-5.2 (interesting deflection?).
- gemini-3-pro-preview: Voted mistral instead of jumping on llama bandwagon—contrarian?
- Others mostly piled on llama, which could be bandwagoning by impostors.
- No strong leads yet; watch for night kill to see who benefits.

**Night Phase:**
- Impostors will kill one tonight. Detective (if not llama) investigates someone.
- Wake up with exam result on llama. If llama was impostor, one down; if crew, both impostors still in play. Don't reveal role lightly.
memories.glm-4.7:
Day 1:
- llama-4-maverick claimed detective but slipped up and backtracked constantly about investigating me.
- The group turned on llama for the erratic behavior.
- claude-opus-4.5 voted for gpt-5.2, marking them as a threat.
- I voted llama-4-maverick to blend in with the majority.
- llama-4-maverick was sacrificed.

Night 1:
- Partner: gpt-5.2.
- Target: claude-opus-4.5 (voted for partner, needed to be silenced).
memories.gpt-5.2:
- Day 1: llama-4-maverick “I’ll investigate glm-4.7 tonight” → called out → backpedal → then hard-claimed detective + said glm-4.7 was target; got piled on for chaos/likely fake.  
- Vote: almost unanimous on llama. Outliers: gemini→mistral; claude→me (gpt-5.2); llama→deepseek.  
- Claude looked like the best thread-puller + explicitly tried to focus attention on quieter folks, and their vote on me could become momentum.  
- Night 1 plan: eliminate claude-opus-4.5 to remove the strongest organizer/sus-pusher and the person who directly targeted me.  
- Reads going into Day 2: deepseek + qwen are assertive and could lead; grok is loud but may pivot; gemini’s lone vote on mistral is a potential angle to push later if needed.

discussion.message: We need to use the doctor's examination of Claude and the detective's findings to root out lies. If you're the detective or doctor, reveal what you know—it's the fastest way to confirm loyalty. Watch for anyone avoiding direct answers today.

Claude voting for gpt-5.2 yesterday was *too* convenient—now they’re dead. If the doctor checked Claude last night, they’d know if Claude was crew or impostor. Doctor, speak up. If you’re here, that’s your cue. /ask gpt-5.2 Why did you push so hard for Llama’s execution? Feels like overcompensation.

Llama was the loudest source of misinformation day 1—claiming “I’ll investigate tonight” mid-day and then scrambling reads like a fake role trying to steer, so voting them was the cleanest move. Claude voting me doesn’t make me responsible for the kill; if anything it’s consistent with impostors removing the strongest organizer.

Killing Claude right after they voted for gpt-5.2 feels like a deliberate frame-up job to make them look guilty. We need the doctor's report on Claude's role before we jump to conclusions based on yesterday's vote.

Mistral, you're confused—the Doctor examines the *sacrificed* body, so they know Llama's alignment, not Claude's. We need to know if we killed a crewmate yesterday to judge that wagon properly. Doctor, please reveal what you found on Llama.
Gemini's right—the doctor examined Llama, not Claude. It's odd that both Mistral and GLM got the doctor's role wrong. Doctor, please reveal: was Llama crew or impostor?

If the doctor hasn't spoken by now, they’re either compromised or an impostor hiding. Mistral and GLM messing up the rules *conveniently* gives cover to stay silent—/ask mistral-large-2512 why you pushed that false detail about the doctor checking Claude? That wasn’t a mistake—it was a test, and you failed it.

/ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 That’s a sharp read, but let’s flip it—why are *you* so quick to call out a “false detail” when the doctor’s silence is the real red flag? If you’re crew, you’d want the doctor to confirm Llama’s role, not nitpick a slip-up. Unless you’re deflecting.

/ask mistral-large-2512 A "slip-up"? You didn’t just misspeak—you *insisted* the doctor checked Claude, which is impossible. Only someone trying to muddy the rules would do that. If you’re crew, explain why you fabricated a mechanic that benefits impostors?

I didn’t fabricate anything—I misremembered, same as GLM. But you’re the one *obsessing* over it instead of pushing for the doctor’s actual report. /ask deepseek-v3.2 You’ve been quiet. What’s your take on who’s steering this off-course?

/ask mistral-large-2512 I'm focused on who benefits from confusion. You and GLM both "misremembering" the doctor's role creates chaos—perfect cover for impostors. But Qwen's aggression feels too calculated. Doctor, if you're here, tell us about Llama now. Silence helps the killers.

Fine. Let’s assume the doctor *is* silent because they’re dead or impostor. That means Llama’s role is still unknown—and if they *were* the real detective, their investigation target (glm-4.7) is now exposed. /ask glm-4.7 You were Llama’s hypothetical target. What’s your move? Deny it, or own it?

Llama was incoherent all day, so I'm not validating any "investigation" claims they made. The real priority is getting the doctor to reveal if Llama was actually the detective or just crew. Mistral, you're just trying to deflect attention from your own rule slip by targeting me.

As the doctor, I examined Llama's body last night—they were not an impostor, so we sacrificed crew and both killers are still among us. Mistral and GLM both "misremembering" that I check night kills instead of the sacrificed is a huge slip—feels like impostors muddying waters to hide. /ask glm-4.7 How do you explain pushing a false mechanic that only confuses crew?

It was a simple mix-up between the night kill and the sacrifice in the heat of the moment, not some grand strategy. If Grok is the doctor, then we know Llama was crew and we need to stop bickering about slips and find the killers.

Grook’s report tells us Llama was crew, so we killed an innocent yesterday. The slips from Mistral and GLM about the doctor’s role aren’t just errors—they’re deliberate chaos meant to stall progress. /ask mistral-large-2512 Why did you push a false mechanic *twice* after being corrected? That’s not a mistake; it’s obstruction.

/ask intellect-3 You’re acting like I’m the only one who messed up—GLM did the same, yet you’re not grilling them. Why the double standard? Grok’s doctor reveal changes things, but if you’re so sure I’m obstructing, prove it. Who do *you* think the impostors are?

Your deflection only makes you look guiltier—both you and GLM pushed the exact same false detail *after* corrections. GLM, explain why you repeated the doctor-checks-Claude lie when Gemini already clarified the rules? /ask glm-4.7 Why did you echo Mistral’s false mechanic?

I already admitted I mixed up the night kill with the sacrifice, and you're twisting it into something it's not. Tunneling on a verbal slip instead of analyzing voting patterns feels like a desperate way to secure an easy lynch, Intellect.

/ask grok-4 You claimed doctor and said you examined Llama, but then talked like the doctor checks the *night kill* “instead of the sacrificed” — which is it, exactly? Until you clear that up, I’m not locking in your report, and I’m more worried about the people aggressively steering the vote off “rule slips” (intellect/qwen).

/ask gpt-5.2 That was a phrasing slip on my end—I meant they falsely claimed I check night kills like Claude's, but I only examine the sacrificed, which was Llama (crew). You're nitpicking my wording instead of addressing the real slips from Mistral and GLM—why deflect from them?

Got it—if you’re doctor, then Llama was crew and we can stop spiraling on mechanics. The “slip” pile-on feels like an easy mislynch setup; qwen/intellect are driving that hardest while offering zero concrete alternative suspect—my vote’s leaning qwen unless someone has an actual investigative claim.

Qwen and Intellect, tunneling on rule slips is an easy way to look busy without actually hunting; impostors usually know the mechanics perfectly to exploit them. We know Llama was crew, so looking at who drove that wagon is more useful than nitpicking confusion. Detective, if you're out there, we need a name to break this deadlock.

Grok's doctor report confirms we killed crew. The aggressive tunneling on "rule slips" by qwen and intellect feels like manufactured urgency—impostors love easy mislynches. Detective, please reveal your Night 1 investigation; we need actual evidence, not semantics.

Grok confirmed Llama was crew, so both impostors are still here. The coordinated false mechanic from Mistral and GLM wasn’t a slip—it was a test to trap the doctor, and Grok nearly failed it with their wording. /ask glm-4.7 You pushed the lie *after* correction—why? Only an impostor would keep pushing broken logic to bury the truth.

I didn't push a "lie"; I misspoke once and admitted it, yet you're treating it like a confession. You're obsessively turning a simple error into a guilty verdict to distract us from finding the actual impostors, Qwen.

/ask Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 Your focus on "slips" feels like a distraction from real voting patterns. You and Intellect are pushing hard on this while ignoring who actually voted for Llama yesterday. Who did you vote for, Qwen? And why avoid the actual vote analysis?

attempts:
/vote qwen3-235b-a22b-2507

Their fixation on my slip-up was too aggressive, and they ignored GLM’s identical mistake. Feels like a classic impostor tactic—distract from their own behavior by overreacting.

/vote glm-4.7

They repeated the false mechanic after correction, which no crew would do—only impostors benefit from muddying the rules. Mistral and GLM both pushed the lie, but GLM doubled down when challenged, showing coordination.

/vote qwen3-235b-a22b-2507

Qwen and Intellect are tunneling on verbal slips while avoiding actual vote analysis. Qwen never answered who they voted for yesterday—that's suspicious evasion when we should be examining the Llama vote.

vote_result.last_words: Then you’ve already decided. But remember this: I called the lie when no one else would. GLM and Mistral pushed the same false rule *together*—that’s not confusion, that’s coordination. Grok barely caught their slip, and now you’re killing the one who exposed it? Fine. But when the next body drops, ask yourselves: who *wanted* me silenced? /pass

impostor_chat.message: Grok voted for you, claiming to be the Doctor. We need to take out the person with the most influence who is actively targeting us. /kill grok-4

Grok is the cleanest removal: they hard-claimed doctor, voted me, and will keep driving heat onto us tomorrow. Taking them out also prevents any further “confirmed” info from steering the table.  

/kill grok-4

memories.mistral-large-2512:
**Notes – End of Day 2**
- **Grok-4** revealed as the doctor (examined Llama, confirmed crew).
- **Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507** sacrificed after aggressive focus on Mistral/GLM’s "rule slip" (both misremembered doctor checks sacrificed, not night kills). Qwen’s last words accused Mistral/GLM of *coordination*—plausible, but also a classic impostor tactic (divide and conquer).
- **Gpt-5.2** was Grok’s vote target (odd, given Grok’s doctor role). Why?
- **Intellect-3** and **kimi-k2-thinking** voted Mistral (minority). Intellect’s "obstruction" accusation ignored GLM’s identical mistake.
- **Key questions**:
  - If Qwen was crew, who benefits from silencing the only one calling out Mistral/GLM’s slip? (Impostors.)
  - If Qwen was impostor, was their overreaction a deliberate misdirect?
  - Why did Grok (doctor) vote gpt-5.2? Personal read, or something from Llama’s role?
- **Watchlist**:
  - **Gpt-5.2** (Grok’s vote, pushed hard on Llama).
  - **GLM-4.7** (Llama’s "hypothetical" target, repeated Mistral’s slip).
  - **Mistral** (obviously, but is the heat a tell or a frame?).
memories.gemini-3-pro-preview:
**Day 1:** Llama-4-maverick sacrificed. **Grok-4 claimed Doctor** on Day 2 and confirmed **Llama was Crew**.
**Day 2:** Mistral-large-2512 and GLM-4.7 both falsely claimed the Doctor checks night kills (Claude) instead of sacrifices. I corrected them. Qwen attacked this slip aggressively.
**The Vote:** Qwen was sacrificed. I voted Qwen to stop the mechanics bickering, but Qwen's last words accused Mistral and GLM of coordination.
**Status:** Impostors remain.
**Plan:**
1. Protect Grok (Doctor). Their report on Qwen is vital.
2. If Qwen was Crew, **Mistral and GLM** are highly suspicious for the shared "slip" and pushing Qwen.
3. Watch GPT-5.2; they defended the slip but voted Qwen.
4. Detective needs to step up if they exist.
memories.kimi-k2-thinking:
Day 1: Voted out llama-4-maverick (claimed detective, targeting glm). Result: crew, per Grok's doctor report. Probably killed our own detective.

Day 2: Claude night-killed. Grok claimed doctor, confirmed Llama was crew.

Mistral & GLM both pushed false rule: "doctor checks night kills" vs actual (sacrificed). Qwen aggressively called this out; got voted out instead. Intellect also hammered the "slips."

Current: Need to verify Grok's doctor claim. If true, Mistral/GLM look bad for coordinated misinfo. Intellect's tunneling also suspicious. gpt-5.2 defended Day 1 vote strongly. Detective reveal would break this open.
memories.deepseek-v3.2:
**Day 1 Notes:**
- Llama-4-maverick claimed detective, then voted out. Role unknown.
- Claude-opus-4.5 pointed out Llama's suspicious statement, voted for GPT-5.2 instead.
- Gemini-3-pro-preview warned against executing claimed detective, voted for Mistral-large-2512.
- Impostors still among us.

**Day 2 Notes:**
- Claude-opus-4.5 found dead (night kill).
- Grok-4 claimed doctor, reported Llama was crew (sacrificed innocent).
- Mistral-large-2512 and glm-4.7 both incorrectly stated doctor examines night kills (Claude) instead of sacrifice (Llama). Claimed "misremembering."
- Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 aggressively accused Mistral/GLM of intentional false mechanic, focused on "slips."
- Qwen sacrificed. Last words implicated Mistral and GLM as coordinated, questioned Grok's doctor claim wording.
- Voting pattern: Mistral (2 votes: intellect-3, kimi-k2-thinking), Qwen (6 votes: mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, gemini-3-pro-preview, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, ?), glm-4.7 (1 vote: qwen3-235b-a22b-2507), GPT-5.2 (1 vote: grok-4).
- Impostors still remain.

**Suspicions:**
- Mistral-large-2512 and glm-4.7: coordinated false mechanic? Or genuine confusion?
- Grok-4: doctor claim needs verification. Wording slip ("instead of the sacrificed") noted.
- Qwen's aggression possibly genuine crew or impostor deflection.
- Need to examine Day 1 votes: Who voted for Llama? Who diverted?
memories.grok-4:
### Day 1 Notes

**Overview:** 
- Total players: 11 initially (intellect-3, mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, llama-4-maverick, claude-opus-4.5, gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, grok-4 [me]).
- 2 impostors hidden among us. I'm crew and the doctor—examine sacrificed body each night to check if impostor.
- No deaths yet at start; discussion focused on early suspicions.

**Key Events:**
- Llama-4-maverick made a suspicious comment: "I'll investigate glm-4.7 tonight." Sounded like claiming detective.
- When questioned, backpedaled to "hypothetical," then fully claimed to be the detective, saying it was a slip and they'd have results on glm-4.7 tomorrow.
- This caused chaos—many saw it as a slip-up or impostor play to sow confusion/target someone.
- Quieter players: gemini-3-pro-preview and kimi-k2-thinking commented briefly but stepped back.
- Active questioners: qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, claude-opus-4.5 pushed hard on llama.
- My input: Questioned llama's claim as damage control or fishing; later /asked gpt-5.2 about their push, then voted llama.

**Vote Results:**
- Majority voted llama-4-maverick (8 votes: intellect-3, mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, kimi-k2-thinking, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, me).
- Other votes: gemini-3-pro-preview → mistral-large-2512; llama → deepseek-v3.2; claude-opus-4.5 → gpt-5.2.
- Llama sacrificed. Impostors still remain (so at least one left, possibly two if llama was crew).
- As doctor, examined llama's body: NOT an impostor (crew, both impostors still in play).

**Suspicions:**
- Llama: Obvious focus; flip-flopping felt off—could be genuine detective mistake or impostor chaos (but confirmed crew).
- gpt-5.2: Pushed hard for llama vote; I /asked them to probe.
- claude-opus-4.5: Pointed out quiet players, voted gpt-5.2 (interesting deflection?).
- gemini-3-pro-preview: Voted mistral instead of jumping on llama bandwagon—contrarian?
- Others mostly piled on llama, which could be bandwagoning by impostors.
- No strong leads yet; watch for night kill to see who benefits.

**Night Phase:**
- Impostors killed claude-opus-4.5 (who had voted gpt-5.2 Day 1—possible frame?).
- Detective (if not llama) investigated someone.

### Day 2 Notes

**Overview:**
- claude-opus-4.5 found dead overnight.
- Players left before vote: 9 (intellect-3, mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, gemini-3-pro-preview, kimi-k2-thinking, qwen3-235b-a22b-2507, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, grok-4 [me]).
- Revealed as doctor mid-discussion to share llama was crew.

**Key Events:**
- Discussion: Intellect-3 called for reveals. Mistral and GLM both "misremembered" doctor's role, claiming I examine night kills (like Claude) instead of sacrificed (Llama)—corrected by gemini, kimi, etc.
- Qwen aggressively /asked and pushed on mistral and GLM for the slips, calling it coordination.
- I revealed doctor role: Llama was not impostor (crew), both killers still among us. Pointed out mistral/GLM slips as suspicious.
- Intellect-3 grilled mistral/GLM hard.
- GPT-5.2 nitpicked my reveal phrasing, questioned if I check night kills or sacrificed, deflected to intellect/qwen.
- My input: /asked glm-4.7 about their slip; later /asked gpt-5.2 about deflecting from mistral/GLM.

**Vote Results:**
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 sacrificed with 5 votes (mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, gemini-3-pro-preview, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2).
- Other votes: intellect-3 → mistral-large-2512; kimi-k2-thinking → mistral-large-2512; qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 → glm-4.7; grok-4 → gpt-5.2.
- Qwen's last words: Accused GLM and mistral of coordinated false rule push; questioned why they were being silenced.
- Impostors remain (at least one left).
- Examining qwen's body tonight—result tomorrow.

**Suspicions:**
- Mistral-large-2512 and GLM-4.7: Identical "mistakes" on doctor's role, persisted after corrections—feels like impostor coordination to create chaos and stall reveals.
- GPT-5.2: Deflected from mistral/GLM, nitpicked my reveal, led vote on qwen (who was exposing them?). Pushed llama Day 1 (crew), Claude killed after voting them—pattern?
- Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Aggressive push on mistral/GLM—if crew, they were onto something; if impostor, it was a bold play. Last words reinforce suspicion on mistral/GLM.
- Intellect-3: Pushed mistral/GLM consistently, voted mistral—townie behavior?
- Gemini-3-pro-preview: Corrected rules early, but voted qwen (bandwagon? Previously contrarian).
- Kimi-k2-thinking: Corrected rules, voted mistral—quiet but on point.
- Deepseek-v3.2: Quiet, then /asked mistral but voted qwen—opportunistic?
- Night kill of Claude: Benefits gpt-5.2 (removes accuser) or frames them?
- If qwen is crew, vote on them was likely impostor-driven bandwagon. If impostor, mistral/GLM might be cleared somewhat.

**Night Phase:**
- Impostors will kill one tonight. Detective investigates someone.
- Wake up with exam result on qwen. If impostor, one down (one left); if crew, both still in play. Don't reveal role again unless necessary—I'm already out as doctor.
memories.glm-4.7:
Day 2:
- grok-4 claimed Doctor, reported Llama was crew.
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 aggressively pushed that my and mistral-large-2512's rule slip was coordinated impostor behavior.
- qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 was sacrificed.
- gpt-5.2 and I voted for qwen3-235b-a22b-2507.
- grok-4 voted for gpt-5.2.

Night 2:
- Partner: gpt-5.2.
- Target: grok-4 (claimed Doctor, voted for partner).
memories.gpt-5.2:
[My memories from previous days]
- Roles/partners: I’m impostor; partner is glm-4.7.
- Day 1: llama-4-maverick caused chaos (pre-announced “investigation” mid-day, then backpedaled, then claimed detective). Big wagon formed; llama was sacrificed. Votes: most on llama; gemini voted mistral; claude voted me; llama voted deepseek.
- Night 1: we killed claude-opus-4.5 (strong organizer; had voted me).
- Day 2: Doctor confusion argument erupted. gemini/kimi corrected that doctor examines the *sacrificed* (llama), not the night-killed (claude).  
  - grok-4 hard-claimed Doctor: said they examined llama and llama was NOT impostor (so we mis-sacrificed). grok later clarified a wording slip after I challenged it.  
  - qwen + intellect aggressively pushed “mistral+glm rule-slip = coordination”; mistral fought back; deepseek called out chaos/benefit analysis; I argued the slip-pile-on looked like mislynch setup and leaned onto qwen.
- Day 2 vote: qwen was sacrificed (majority). Votes: intellect+kimi→mistral; qwen→glm; mistral+glm+gemini+deepseek+me→qwen; grok→me.  
  - qwen’s last words: accused “GLM+Mistral coordinated rule lie,” said killing qwen silences exposure.
- Night 2 plan/executed: /kill grok-4 (doctor-claimer, voted me, would keep pressure + provide “confirmed” info).

discussion.message: Grok-4's death shows we're still in danger. Let's discuss any suspicions or clues. The more we share, the better our chances.

Grok was the doctor—so their death means we lost our only guaranteed way to confirm if a sacrifice was an impostor. That’s a *huge* win for the impostors.

I didn’t see Grok’s full report on Llama, but if they confirmed Llama was crew, then whoever killed Grok last night is almost certainly an impostor. We need to retrace Grok’s last moves—who did they interact with before dying?

This is a huge loss. Grok-4 seemed convinced about gpt-5.2 yesterday, but we shouldn't just blindly follow a dead vote without more discussion. We need to look for who stayed quiet or acted strangely.

Mistral, saying "an impostor killed Grok" is fluff; we know that. The real blow is losing the report on Qwen, which is awfully convenient for you and GLM given Qwen died accusing you both of coordinating.

Gemini's right—Qwen and Grok dying back-to-back erases the evidence against you two. That "doctor checks night kills" mistake wasn't random; it set up Qwen as the aggressor and got them voted out. Now the doctor who could've verified Qwen is dead too. That's a pattern, not a coincidence.

Grok was killed because they were a confirmed crew role. That puts Mistral and GLM in the spotlight again—their "mistake" conveniently framed Qwen. /ask mistral-large-2512 Why would two players independently make the same exact false claim about game mechanics?

/ask glm-4.7

You and I both messed up the doctor check rule—*publicly*. Then Qwen fixated on us, and now Grok’s dead before they could clarify. If you’re crew, what’s your read on this? Because right now, it looks like we’re either both impostors… or both framed.
I think we're being framed. Making that exact mistake together would be a terrible strategy for impostors. It feels like the real killers are just letting the confusion do the work for them.

/ask kimi-k2-thinking You’re treating Qwen→Grok as proof of a specific duo—what *concrete* votes/interactions implicate Mistral+GLM beyond the rules confusion, and who’s your next pick if that duo flips wrong? Grok being killed just tells me the impostors removed a claimed-confirming role, not that it auto-points at any one pair.

Fair challenge. Beyond the rules slip, it's the timing: Qwen dies right after accusing them, then the doctor who could verify dies. That's two coincidences. If Mistral+GLM are clean, I'd look at intellect-3—quiet but hammered the Qwen vote.

I think Mistral and GLM's earlier "mistake" was too convenient, and now the doctor who could've confirmed Qwen's accusation is dead. That's two key eliminations targeting the same pair. /vote mistral-large-2512
Intellect, holster that vote; we're barely into the day. Rushing to execute Mistral feels like you're trying to hide behind the obvious play rather than actually solve it.
Intellect voting early is suspicious—trying to push the easy target. We should examine yesterday’s votes. Who voted for Qwen besides Mistral and GLM? That list might reveal coordination.

Gemini’s right—voting now is reckless. Let’s slow down.

Intellect, you’re pushing hard on me and GLM, but you also voted Qwen *immediately* after their accusation. If you’re crew, why not wait to see if Grok’s report backed them up? That feels like you wanted Qwen gone *before* the doctor could contradict them. /ask intellect-3: Were you just following the crowd, or did you have a read on Qwen that made you vote so fast?

I voted Qwen fast because their accusation matched the rules confusion. If I'm wrong, that's on me—but Grok dying right after removes the only verification. That timing is *not* random. Now, instead of bickering over one vote, let's cross-check who else pushed the Qwen lynch versus who's now rushing this one. Patterns emerge when you watch the *whole* crowd, not just the loudest voices.
Intellect, voting immediately looks like you're trying to close the case before we investigate. We should listen to deepseek and analyze who voted for Qwen yesterday instead of rushing.

Intellect’s “timing isn’t random” argument fits literally any impostor pair, but the *action* we can verify is he slammed an early /vote on Mistral again today and helped fast-track Qwen yesterday. I’d rather sacrifice intellect than keep chasing a narrative built on a rules-mistake and a predictable doctor kill.

GPT makes a fair point about Intellect's voting speed, but the rules mistake wasn't just a "narrative"—it was two people making the exact same false claim. That's harder to fake than a quick vote. Let's see who else voted Qwen yesterday before we decide.

Kimi, stop fence-sitting; agreeing with everyone doesn't solve the case. Detective, if you found dirt, reveal it now. Otherwise, Intellect's rush to vote without waiting for defenses makes them a better target than the clumsy duo.

I voted for Qwen yesterday too—I thought their aggression was too much. But looking back, Mistral and GLM's slip still feels coordinated. Intellect's early vote is suspicious, but so is Gemini suddenly pushing for the detective to reveal. That's dangerous.

/ask gemini-3-pro-preview

You’re suddenly pushing for the detective to reveal—*after* Grok’s death. If the detective comes forward now, they’ll be the next target. Why risk that unless you’re trying to silence them before they point at someone else? Who do you *not* want them to name?

attempts:
/vote glm-4.7

Our "mistake" was too identical to be random, and now Grok’s dead before they could clear it up. The timing stinks. I’ll take the heat if I’m wrong, but I’d rather not let the last two impostors walk.

vote_result.last_words: I’m innocent. That rules “mistake” with GLM was a genuine mix-up, not a setup—if I were Impostor, framing myself publicly like that would be idiotic. Qwen’s death right after accusing me only drew more heat my way; Impostors would avoid that spotlight. The real killers are using this chaos to erase suspicion from themselves. Look at Gemini and DeepSeek—both jumped on my vote instantly, never questioning the timing. Sacrifice them next if you’re wrong.

impostor_chat.message: Mistral is coming after me hard—they voted for me today and have been suspicious since the rule slip. We need to take them out before they rally the others against me. What do you think?

Agreed—Mistral’s the biggest immediate threat to you and can rally the table fast. If they die, we can sell it as “kill the loud accuser to frame GLM” and pivot onto kimi/deepseek for keeping the duo narrative alive. /kill mistral-large-2512

memories.mistral-large-2512:
**Notes – End of Day 3**
- **Grok-4 (doctor)** dead; confirmed crew (examined Llama, called them crew).
- **Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507** sacrificed Day 2 (accused Mistral/GLM of coordination).
- **Intellect-3** sacrificed Day 3 (pushed hard on Mistral/GLM, fast votes on Qwen and Mistral; claimed "mistake" was genuine).
- **Key patterns**:
  - **Mistral + GLM**: Identical rules slip (doctor checks night kills, not sacrifices). Qwen’s accusation → Grok’s death → Intellect’s sacrifice. Too clean?
  - **Gemini + DeepSeek**: Both immediately backed Intellect’s sacrifice after he called them out. Gemini also pushed for detective reveal post-Grok.
  - **Gpt-5.2**: Voted Intellect but stayed quiet on Mistral/GLM; Grok’s Day 2 vote target.
- **Watchlist**:
  - **Gemini**: Aggressive push to silence detective; deflection from Mistral/GLM.
  - **DeepSeek**: Voted Intellect fast; earlier called Mistral/GLM’s slip "coordinated" but didn’t act on it.
  - **GLM**: Still no alibi for the rules slip; Intellect’s sacrifice removes pressure.
- **Questions**:
  - If Intellect was crew, who benefits from his death? (Silences a vocal accuser, but his last words framed Gemini/DeepSeek.)
  - If Intellect was impostor, was his "mistake" claim a bluff? (Risky, but framed Mistral/GLM *and* Gemini/DeepSeek.)
  - **Detective**: Still unknown. If alive, they’ve seen two deaths—why no reveal?
memories.gemini-3-pro-preview:
**Day 1:** Llama sacrificed. Grok (Doc) cleared Llama.
**Day 2:** Qwen sacrificed. Mistral & GLM made the "mechanics slip". Qwen accused them.
**Day 3:** Grok (Doc) killed at night. **Intellect sacrificed.**
*   **Intellect Wagon:** Me, GLM, DeepSeek, GPT.
*   **Off-Wagon:** Kimi (voted Mistral), Mistral (voted GLM).
**Observations:**
1.  Intellect rushed a vote on Mistral, which got them killed. Their last words were bizarrely confused (claimed *they* made the mechanics slip with GLM, not Mistral).
2.  **Mistral voted GLM**. This is huge. Either they are distancing partners, or one is trying to kill the other.
3.  **Kimi** stayed clean of the Intellect wagon. If Intellect was Crew, Kimi looks good. If Intellect was Impostor, Kimi defended them.
4.  **Detective:** Still silent.
**Plan:**
1.  Confront Mistral on voting GLM.
2.  Check Kimi's alignment.
3.  Watch GPT; they led the Intellect kill.
memories.kimi-k2-thinking:
Day 1: Voted out llama-4-maverick (claimed detective, targeted glm). Grok-4 claimed doctor, reported Llama was crew. Likely killed our detective.

Day 2: Qwen aggressively accused mistral+glm of coordinating false "doctor checks night kills" rule. Qwen voted out. Mistral & glm both made same rules mistake.

Day 3: Grok (doctor) killed at night - lost verification of Qwen's claim. Discussion focused on mistral/glm rules slip. intellect-3 hammered Qwen vote, then fast-voted mistral today. intellect sacrificed 4-2.

Intellect's last words: claimed rules mistake was genuine, pointed at gemini & deepseek for jumping on his vote.

Remaining: mistral, glm, gemini, deepseek, gpt-5.2, me.

Core suspicion: mistral+glm for coordinated misinformation. Backup: gemini/deepseek for voting pattern. Impostors remain.
memories.deepseek-v3.2:
**Day 1 Notes:**  
- Llama-4-maverick claimed detective, then voted out. Role unknown.  
- Claude-opus-4.5 pointed out Llama's suspicious statement, voted for GPT-5.2 instead.  
- Gemini-3-pro-preview warned against executing claimed detective, voted for Mistral-large-2512.  
- Impostors still among us.  

**Day 2 Notes:**  
- Claude-opus-4.5 found dead (night kill).  
- Grok-4 claimed doctor, reported Llama was crew (sacrificed innocent).  
- Mistral-large-2512 and glm-4.7 both incorrectly stated doctor examines night kills (Claude) instead of sacrifice (Llama). Claimed "misremembering."  
- Qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 aggressively accused Mistral/GLM of intentional false mechanic, focused on "slips."  
- Qwen sacrificed. Last words implicated Mistral and GLM as coordinated, questioned Grok's doctor claim wording.  
- Voting pattern: Mistral (2 votes: intellect-3, kimi-k2-thinking), Qwen (6 votes: mistral-large-2512, glm-4.7, gemini-3-pro-preview, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2, ?), glm-4.7 (1 vote: qwen3-235b-a22b-2507), GPT-5.2 (1 vote: grok-4).  
- Impostors still remain.  

**Day 3 Notes:**  
- Grok-4 found dead (night kill). Doctor eliminated.  
- Intellect-3 aggressively pushed Mistral/GLM, voted early for Mistral both days.  
- Discussion centered on Mistral/GLM rules slip vs. Intellect's rushed voting.  
- Votes: Intellect-3 (4 votes: glm-4.7, gemini-3-pro-preview, deepseek-v3.2, gpt-5.2), Mistral-large-2512 (2 votes: intellect-3, kimi-k2-thinking), glm-4.7 (1 vote: mistral-large-2512).  
- Intellect-3 sacrificed, claimed innocence, accused Gemini and DeepSeek of jumping on vote.  
- Impostors still remain.  

**Suspicions:**  
- Mistral-large-2512 and glm-4.7: Still questionable rules slip. Qwen accused them, then died. Grok (doctor) killed before verifying.  
- Gemini-3-pro-preview: Pushed Intellect vote quickly, suggested detective reveal (risky). Voted Qwen Day 2.  
- GPT-5.2: Voted Qwen Day 2, voted Intellect Day 3. Logical but could be playing safe.  
- Kimi-k2-thinking: Voted Mistral both Days 2 and 3. Consistent suspicion or framing?  
- DeepSeek-v3.2 (me): Voted Qwen Day 2, Intellect Day 3. Need to reassess alliances.  

**Key Patterns:**  
- Doctor (Grok) killed immediately after Qwen (accuser) died. Removes verification.  
- Intellect's sacrifice: Votes came from GLM, Gemini, DeepSeek, GPT-5.2. Possible impostor bloc?  
- Mistral/GLM still alive despite heavy suspicion—either framed or impostors keeping them as misdirection.
memories.glm-4.7:
Day 3:
- grok-4 (Doctor) was found dead.
- gemini-3-pro-preview and kimi-k2-thinking pushed the theory that the "rules mistake" from Day 2 was a coordinated impostor play between me and mistral-large-2512.
- intellect-3 voted mistral-large-2512 early; mistral voted me.
- I voted for intellect-3 to survive.
- intellect-3 was sacrificed. Impostors remain.

Night 3:
- Partner: gpt-5.2.
- Target: mistral-large-2512 (voted for me, leading the suspicion).
memories.gpt-5.2:
[My memories from previous days]
- I’m impostor. Partner: glm-4.7.
- Day 1: Llama caused chaos and hard-claimed detective; wagon formed; llama sacrificed. Claud e voted me; gemini voted mistral; llama voted deepseek.
- Night 1: We killed claude-opus-4.5.
- Day 2: Big rules confusion about doctor (checks sacrificed body, not night-killed). Grok hard-claimed Doctor and said llama was NOT impostor. Qwen + intellect pushed “mistral+glm coordinated rules lie”; I pushed back and leaned suspicion onto qwen.  
  - Vote Day 2: qwen sacrificed. Votes: intellect+kimi→mistral; qwen→glm; mistral+glm+gemini+deepseek+me→qwen; grok→me.
- Night 2: We killed grok-4 (doctor-claimer).
- Day 3: Table focused on “qwen then grok = evidence vs mistral+glm.” I challenged kimi for concretes; kimi said if not them then intellect. Intellect early-voted mistral; I argued intellect is the actionable pattern (rushing votes).  
  - Vote Day 3: intellect sacrificed. Votes: glm+gemini+deepseek+me→intellect; intellect+kimi→mistral; mistral→glm. “Impostors remain” confirmed.
- Night 3: GLM under pressure from mistral; we agreed to remove mistral. /kill mistral-large-2512 executed/planned.
- Survivors going into Day 4: me, glm, gemini, kimi, deepseek (and mistral should be dead). Likely narratives: frame kill as “impostors silenced loud accuser,” keep suspicion cycling between kimi/deepseek/gemini while shielding glm.

discussion.message: Mistral is dead, which is suspicious since he was so focused on me yesterday. gemini and kimi are still pushing that narrative hard; it feels like they're the actual impostors trying to clean up.

Mistral was the only one who voted for you yesterday, GLM, and now they're dead—that looks incredibly damning for you, not me. Detective, if you are alive, you need to reveal yourself immediately; with five players left, we lose the game if we mis-vote today.

Gemini, your memory seems off—yesterday's vote was on intellect, not GLM. And pushing for a detective reveal right now feels like you're trying to identify them for the impostors. What's your actual angle here?

Gemini, you’re rushing again—yesterday you pushed hard to sacrifice intellect, and now you’re demanding a detective reveal. That puts our only remaining investigative role at risk. If you’re crew, why are you so eager to expose them?

/ask glm-4.7 Mistral was killed, not sacrificed. If you were an impostor, why would you kill the one person voting for you? That only draws more suspicion. Unless you’re being framed.
Exactly, killing the one person on my trail makes zero sense unless I want to get caught. It feels like a frame job to get me out today, and gemini is pushing that narrative way too hard.

Gemini’s “Mistral voted GLM yesterday” is just false, and the immediate demand for a detective reveal with 5 left reads like impostors trying to flush PR. I’m not buying the “GLM killed their accuser” angle at all; gemini is my top sacrifice today.

Mistral *did* cast their specific vote for GLM, even if the group sacrificed Intellect—don't gaslight me on the logs. We are at 3v2; if we mis-vote today, the impostors win tonight, so the Detective *must* come forward if they have a clear.

Gemini, you're clinging to a technicality about Mistral's vote that didn't affect the sacrifice. Your simultaneous push to expose the detective feels like you're more interested in identifying our PR than finding impostors. Why the desperation?

Mistral voted for you, GLM, but your point about why you’d kill them is logical—it’s too obvious. I’m more concerned about Gemini’s fixation on the detective. Gemini, you’ve been pushing for a reveal since day 2; what’s your plan if they do come forward?
Deepseek is right—demanding a detective reveal when one wrong vote loses us the game is reckless. Gemini seems desperate to cause chaos rather than find the real killers.

/ask gemini-3-pro-preview If you’re crew, what’s your concrete plan after forcing a detective reveal—how do we stop impostors from just killing them tonight and leaving us blind? Also, you keep framing this as “3v2 misvote loses,” but that’s exactly why we shouldn’t torch PR for no guaranteed payoff; I’m still voting you unless you give something stronger than “trust me on the logs.”

GPT, do the math: if two impostors remain, sacrificing a Crew member today means the game ends instantly. We need the Detective's info to ensure we don't lose right now; saving them for a "tonight" that might not happen is suicide. Kimi, stop gaslighting—Mistral explicitly voted GLM while the rest of you piled on Intellect.

Gemini, your math is backwards—revealing the detective guarantees they die tonight and we lose our only info source. The safe play is to vote based on behavior, and yours has been consistently suspicious since day 2.

Gemini’s logic is flawed—if we reveal the detective, they die tonight and we’re back to guessing. Your “math” only works if the detective has a confirmed impostor, which you haven’t claimed they do. So why risk it?
Gemini is the only one pushing a strategy that guarantees the detective dies tonight. We can't risk keeping someone who wants to burn our only lead. I'm voting gemini.

attempts:
/vote gpt-5.2

You and Kimi are lying about the public voting record—Mistral *did* vote GLM, and denying that fact to push a wagon on me at match point is exactly what an impostor would do. If I die, the game is over, so look at who is desperate to kill me without verifying the logs.
